chunk: Hemoglobin: Hemoglobin is a protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen. Low levels may indicate anemia.
Hematocrit: Hematocrit is the percentage of blood volume occupied by red blood cells. Low levels can indicate anemia.
RBC Count: RBC (Red Blood Cell) count measures how many red blood cells you have. It helps assess oxygen transport.
WBC Count: WBC (White Blood Cell) count measures the number of white blood cells in your blood. It helps fight infection.
Platelet Count: Platelets are cells that help your blood clot. Low counts may cause excessive bleeding or bruising.
MCV: MCV (Mean Corpuscular Volume) indicates the average size of your red blood cells. It helps diagnose anemia types.
MCH: MCH (Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin) is the average amount of hemoglobin per red blood cell.
MCHC: MCHC (Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration) measures the concentration of hemoglobin in red blood cells.
RDW: RDW (Red Cell Distribution Width) measures variation in red blood cell size. High RDW may indicate anemia.
Neutrophils: Neutrophils are a type of white blood cell that fight bacterial infections. High levels may indicate infection.
Lymphocytes: Lymphocytes are white blood cells that play a key role in your immune system. Low levels can indicate immune issues.
Monocytes: Monocytes are white blood cells that help break down bacteria. Elevated levels can suggest inflammation.
Eosinophils: Eosinophils help fight allergies and parasitic infections.
Basophils: Basophils are the least common type of WBC but are involved in allergic reactions.
Total Cholesterol: Total Cholesterol measures all cholesterol in your blood. High levels increase heart disease risk.
HDL: HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein) is the 'good' cholesterol. Higher levels are better for heart health.
LDL: LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein) is the 'bad' cholesterol. High levels increase heart disease risk.
VLDL: VLDL (Very Low-Density Lipoprotein) carries triglycerides. High levels can contribute to heart disease.
Triglycerides: Triglycerides are a type of fat in the blood. Elevated levels are a risk factor for heart disease.
CHOL/HDL Ratio: CHOL/HDL Ratio is used to estimate heart disease risk. A lower ratio is generally better.
LDL/HDL Ratio: LDL/HDL Ratio compares bad to good cholesterol. Higher values indicate more risk.
Sodium: Sodium helps regulate fluids and nerve function. Imbalances can cause confusion or seizures.
Potassium: Potassium is critical for heart and muscle function. Too high or low can be dangerous.
Chloride: Chloride helps maintain fluid balance and blood pressure.
Bicarbonate: Bicarbonate helps regulate blood pH balance.
BUN: BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen) measures kidney function. Elevated levels may indicate kidney problems.
Creatinine: Creatinine is a waste product measured to assess kidney function.
eGFR: eGFR estimates how well your kidneys are filtering blood. Lower values indicate worse function.
Glucose: Glucose measures blood sugar. It is used to screen for and manage diabetes.
HbA1c: HbA1c reflects average blood sugar over the past 3 months. It is used to diagnose and monitor diabetes.
ALT: ALT (Alanine Aminotransferase) is a liver enzyme. High levels can indicate liver damage.
AST: AST (Aspartate Aminotransferase) is a liver enzyme. It's often tested with ALT.
ALP: ALP (Alkaline Phosphatase) is an enzyme related to bile ducts. High levels may suggest liver or bone issues.
Bilirubin: Bilirubin is a pigment processed by the liver. High levels may cause jaundice.
Albumin: Albumin is a protein made by the liver. Low levels can indicate liver or kidney problems.
Total Protein: Total Protein measures all proteins in blood. Abnormal levels can reflect liver or nutritional issues.
CRP: CRP (C-Reactive Protein) is a marker of inflammation. High levels can indicate infection or chronic disease.
ESR: ESR (Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate) is a nonspecific marker of inflammation.
Ferritin: Ferritin reflects stored iron in the body. Low levels may indicate iron deficiency.
Vitamin D: Vitamin D helps with calcium absorption and bone health. Low levels can lead to bone problems.
Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 is vital for nerves and blood cell production. Deficiency may cause fatigue or neuropathy.
Folate: Folate is essential for DNA synthesis and red blood cell production.
Calcium: Calcium supports bones, teeth, muscles, and nerves.
Phosphorus: Phosphorus helps build bones and is involved in energy metabolism.
Magnesium: Magnesium is involved in muscle, nerve, and enzyme function.
Iron: Iron is needed for red blood cell production. Low levels lead to anemia.
TSH: TSH (Thyroid Stimulating Hormone) controls thyroid hormone production. High or low levels indicate thyroid problems.
T3: T3 (Triiodothyronine) is a thyroid hormone affecting metabolism.
T4: T4 (Thyroxine) is a key hormone regulating metabolism and energy.
Testosterone: Testosterone is a hormone important for sexual function and muscle mass.
FSH: FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone) regulates reproductive processes.
LH: LH (Luteinizing Hormone) helps regulate ovulation and testosterone.
Cortisol: Cortisol is a stress hormone that affects metabolism and immune response.
Insulin: Insulin controls blood sugar levels. Abnormal levels are linked to diabetes.
D-Dimer: D-Dimer is a protein fragment from blood clots. High levels suggest clotting problems.
Procalcitonin: Procalcitonin is a marker of bacterial infection and sepsis.
Troponin: Troponin is released when the heart muscle is damaged. High levels suggest a heart attack.
BNP: BNP (Brain Natriuretic Peptide) is elevated in heart failure.
NT-proBNP: NT-proBNP helps diagnose and monitor heart failure.
ANA: ANA (Antinuclear Antibody) is used to detect autoimmune diseases like lupus.
HIV: HIV tests detect the human immunodeficiency virus.
Hepatitis B: Hepatitis B tests detect viral infection affecting the liver.
Hepatitis C: Hepatitis C tests check for chronic liver infection.
